awd_titl_txt: MRI:  Acquisition of Aquilos Dual-Beam Microscope
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to the University of California San Diego to support the acquisition of a cryo-dual beam microscope to enable the three dimensional visualization of cells at the level of the structure of individual biomolecules. This technology will enable the development of completely novel hypothesis on how molecules perform their function within the molecular landscapes that they operate in. This project will realize this potential for laboratories at UC San Diego,  and will extend the training opportunities from technically trained scientists to non-expert users, effectively democratizing this technology and training the next generation of instrumentalists from diverse backgrounds.  Furthermore, the molecular landscapes that this project will reveal are great teaching and dissemination tools for general audiences, including the creation and circulation of virtual reality and videos that allow users to navigate and explore cellular territories from within.  

The acquisition of this instrument will support research projects that aim to observe intricate molecular networks in their natural environment. The scientific projects it will support  span from technical projects that aim to develop new methodologies that will leverage the use of cryo-FIB milling for structural cell biology, to biologically driven projects with goals of unveiling the molecular mechanisms that result from specialized molecular networks in various model systems in cell biology. Method-related projects include development of novel computational algorithms to identify proteins within the molecular panoramas and enabling simulations of entire cells to predict cellular behavior under a variety of perturbations.  Biologically driven projects include: unveiling unexplored mechanisms in bacterial cell biology, such as how bacterial cells divide and differentiate, how they respond to viral infection or keep track of time; the study of fundamental processes in the nucleus of eukaryotic cells such as how the genome organizes in 3-D and how this architecture determines the state of the cell. Together with future projects that will be enabled by this technology, the awarded project has the potential to make transformative discoveries that will unleash yet-unimagined hypothesis of cellular mechanisms in a wide range of biological scenarios.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This instrument supported research projects that aim to observe intricate molecular networks in their natural environment.  The projects involved many principal investigators and collaborations that supported various research areas ranging from a broad range of fields in biology. Biologically driven projects included: (i)  unveiling unexplored mechanisms in bacterial cell biology, such as bacterial engulfment, the generation of a nucleus-like structure in bacteria after being infected by a new class of viruses named jumbo phage, and the molecular mechanisms of circadian rhythms by exploring the molecular large-scale organization of proteins involved in the simplest circadian clock known; (ii) the study of fundamental processes in the nucleus of eukaryotic cells such as how the nuclear pore complex regulates transport to and from the nucleus of the cell, ensuring that the genome is protected while maintaining its function; (iii) what is the role of phase separation in molecular organization and function, with examples both in bacteria and inside the eukaryotic nucleus; and (iv) what are the molecular mechanisms underlying cellular dysfunction leading to diseases like Parkinson?s. Further, the instrument supported the advancement of computational technologies to analyze the data generated by this technology.   

The project had very productive outcomes: 

(1)   Over 20 trainees and staff scientists trained to use the instrument. These scientists are now working in biological research, either in academia or industry, and not only continue to use these skills but are actively training others in the community.

(2)   To date, ten research papers supported by this grant have been published, covering various topics described above. The papers were published in the journals with the highest impact in scientific research, including Nature, Science, Cell, PNAS, and eLife.  Further, we published three manuscripts that helped disseminate the technology to a broader audience in the form of a Nature Protocols paper and two book chapters. 

(3)   Thanks to the availability of this instrument, research grants have been funded by different private and public agencies including NIH, ASAP, HHMI, and Pew as well as pre- and post-doctoral fellowships funded by the Damon Runyon Cancer Research Foundation, the American Heart Association, EMBO, the Life Sciences Research Foundation, and the Jane Coffin Child Memorial Fund. The total funds awarded since the installation of the instrument surpass $20M; in all of these projects the dual beam is a central instrument to carry out the proposed work.  

 

Broader impacts. The technique of cryo-FIB milling of cells had been restricted to a handful of laboratories in the world that required to build in-house adaptations to make the instrument work effectively. On the other hand, these laboratories, including that of the PI, have made fundamental biological discoveries using these tools, and thus the interest in this technology is growing. At UCSD, many more projects and investigators could access this technology thanks to the purchase of this instrument and has allowed us to train the next generation of instrumentalists from diverse backgrounds. The significance of our work is evident by coverage on news pieces in scientific journals: Democratizing cryo-EM, Science, 2020 (DOI: 10.1126/science.367.6484.1394-b) and Calling Cell Biologists to try cryo-ET, Nature Methods, 2018 (DOI: 10.1038/s41592-018-0079-y). Last but not least, we have participated in science dissemination to the general public. As examples, our work was covered in an article in the New Yorker: A Journey into the Center of our Cells (March 7, 2022 Issue), and in the CBS show Mission Unstoppable!, that highlights female innovators who are on the cutting edge of science designed for a female teen audience to empower young women and showcase the many ways they can impact the world through careers in STEM

 


Last Modified: 01/29/2023
Modified by: Elizabeth Villa
